entry.title: Exploit-Exercises: Protostar (Stack Levels)
entry.content:
Image: Exploit-Exercises: Protostar (v2)

Protostar Stack0

Protostar Stack1

Protostar Stack2

Protostar Stack3

We need to rewrite fp function address with the address of win().

Protostar Stack4

We use metasploit patterns (on Kali Linux) to determine the exact location of stored EIP:

Protostar Stack5

The idea is the same as in Stack4, but we need to store shellcode on stack, for example.

Stack is executable:

To have the same address in bash and gdb, we use hellman’s fixenv tool.

The address 0xbffff820 represents the buffer[] address, we store our shellcode here and jump to this address. Also we know, that return address is overwritten after position 76, from Protostar Stack4. We created our shellcode here.

The shell is executed, however it receives EOF. For this purposes, we can keep it alive with cat command:

Sometimes a more convenient solution could be storing shellcode in environment:

We do not need to use r.sh again - the EGG address could be easily calculated (albeit it’s different, because fixenv clears our environment):

entry.title: IA-32 Linux Shellcode Basics 2
entry.content:
Starting with the ASM code that is position dependent:

The minimalistic shell could look like execve("/bin/sh", NULL, NULL). However, according documentation it’s not portable among UNIX systems:

Again, the same procedure. We need to get rid of absolute address reference and NULL bytes.

Before we dump our opcodes, we add setreuid(geteuid(), geteuid() call:

Analogously as before:

Alternatively we can obtain string reference with call instruction:

The segfault is normal and it’s because we are trying to overwrite the code segment at the line mov BYTE PTR [ebx+0x7],cl. Because our shellcode will be loaded on stack, that doesn’t mean any complication.

entry.title: IA-32 Linux Shellcode Basics 1
entry.content:
We start with the simple shellcode, that prints hello string. For this purpose, we use Kali Linux 32 bit distribution, that could be downloaded here.

Because we want to have code as simple as possible, we use tcc ansi compiler and nasm assembler.

As we can see, the string is located at 0x08049304 address. However, our code should be Position Independent (PIE) and without NULL characters.

To rewrite the code about, we need to:

  • Look up the number corresponding to the system call in /usr/include/i386-linux-gnu/asm/unistd_32.h
  • Place system call number in eax, and arguments in ebx, ecx, edx… in the order they appear in the corresponding man page
  • Execute int 0x80 to alert the kernel we want to perform a system call

Our first try:

Dumping instruction bytecode:

When we set 32b register with a small value, the compiler fills the unused space with zeros. Instead, we should use AX = 16b or AL = 8b register parts (in the case of register EAX).

Next try:

We attempt to make the code position independent pushing string to the stack:

Now it looks good, but the 0x0a could sometimes terminate the buffer prematurely, so we simply do not use this character.

Now we parse out the opcodes and validate the functionality.

If we want to store shellcode to the file:

Our next step will be to execute shell.

entry.title: Exploit-Exercises: Nebula (16-19)
entry.content:
Image: Exploit-Exercises: Nebula (v5)

Level16

There is a perl script running on port 1616, source:

The service is running with flag16 privileges:

Clearly, there is RCE vulnerability (line 14), we can check it creating an arbitrary file:

Only problem is that input is uppercased and everything after whitespace character is stripped:

We tried several other methods without success. In the later case, the shell runs, but we cannot do anything useful:

Our solution was to create uppercased file in /tmp/ and use * expansion, telling bash to find the correct directory.

Level17

According documentation it is not safe to use data from untrusted source, so pickle.loads on line 14 means RCE:

Warning The pickle module is not intended to be secure against erroneous or maliciously constructed data. Never unpickle data received from an untrusted or unauthenticated source.

Our exploit for executing remote shell:

Level18

According challenge info, there are several ways how to solve this challenge.

First thing that we tried was to use parameter -d /home/flag18/password to rewrite password file with the known output, however the strcmp() doesn’t match for the reason that we cannot insert the newline character to the end of our string.

The fclose() on line 34 is not aligned, that’s strange. We found out that this call is not used in the binary file:

We can use login function to exhaust file descriptors, because when the fopen() fails, we will be logged in. After a few tries:

We used closelog to close one used descriptor and the shell is invoked, unfortunately we need to get rid of -d parameter too, bash is recycling our argv, see execve("/bin/sh", argv, envp);.

We tried --init-file as it has the second argument some file:

Second way is to use format string exploitation, line 48 is vulnerable at notsupported() function.

For debugging, we downloaded gdb-peda:

Because the Fortify2, there was no easy way to solve it, technique from phrack #67 could be very useful.

There is also buffer overflow in setuser() function, that doesn’t seem to be exploitable.

Level19

To pass the last challenge, our process parent id should match uid 0. This could be easily achieved when the parent dies and the orphan process is adopted by init.

Exploit:

Binding shell to port 2448, binary will be called from exploit.

entry.title: Exploit-Exercises: Nebula (11-15)
entry.content:
Image: Exploit-Exercises: Nebula (v5)

Level11

According to the assignment, there should be two ways how to exploit the source below.

The fread(buf, length, 1, stdin) always returns 1 as we can read in the unix manual: fread() and fwrite() return the number of items successfully read or written (i.e., not the number of characters).

Here if(length < sizeof(buf)) { we have two ways to progress. I suppose having two solutions means calling process() from the different parts of code.

The first way is setting “Content-Length: 1”. The buffer is XORed using the simple algorithm below, this time the ‘for’ cycle runs only once.

Because the buffer with ‘A’ character is not NULL terminated and contains uninitialized data, we use the technique described here Controlling uninitialized memory with LD_PRELOAD to have more luck with terminating ‘A’.

The getflag runs, albeit there is a bug in the binary, because the new process is created using system(), so it wasn’t possible to get flag11 privileges.

The second way is to use input with the length at least 1024. The decryption routine is almost symmetric. However, in this step key -= buffer[i]; we need to substract from key the original value, so we XOR it with the key again.

Level12

The code below should be backdoored:

With io.popen we can invoke arbitrary command using several techniques. We use command substitution and two screens to gain reverse shell using bash:

Level13

The vulnerable program checks if the user does match the specific user id.

Because we know where the value 0x3e8 = 1000 is used to compare with eax, now we need only to tamper this value:

As another solution we use the PRELOAD library. We use the copy of flag13, because the restriction with invoking preload with suid binaries.

Level14

The encryption process is trivial, on each byte position, the /home/flag14/flag14 add the position index to the ascii value of the character, started by 0, see:

Now we use the reverse process to decrypt the token:

Level15

From strace output we can see that the binary is trying to link shared library from /var/tmp/flag15 directory:

We try to provide this library (in /var/tmp/flag15/libc.so.6):

There is an error, because we are linking using GLIBC_2.1.3, but in the binary, there are two symbols with GLIBC_2.0 undefined:

We provide version script to the linker, link statically and try the same thing again.

The second way how to solve the challenge is without linking libc, writing assembler code. For this purpose we used nasm assembler, everything needed for the compilation process was already on the nebula iso.

entry.title: Exploit-Exercises: Nebula (06-10)
entry.content:
Image: Exploit-Exercises: Nebula (v5)

Level06

From the assignment “The flag06 account credentials came from a legacy unix system” we conclude that the password is stored in /etc/passwd.

We store credentials to /tmp/hash.txt and use john:

Now we can log using ‘hello’ password:

Level07

The configuration file is stored in ‘/home/flag07/thttpd.conf’.

Because there is no input validation, we have RCE:

Inspired by Reverse Shell Cheat Sheet

we can create reverse shell on port 1337 via bash, using ruby to encode our payload:

In the window with nc, we got:

Level08

We can see from the output above that 0x7f represents delete keystore, so the password we are looking for is ‘backd00Rmate’

Level09

Because the flag09 binary is interpreted via php shell, there is a trivial solution:

Second way how to solve this challenge is to use PCRE pattern modifiers vulnerability in PREG_REPLACE_EVAL.

Because we cannot use quotes, we can inject something with complex (curly) syntax, that could be used for strings representation.

Here the second argument $use_me is invoked:

Actually, I have found the third solution without using $use_me parameter, but recycling $filename:

Level10

What to do is immediately clear, there is a race condition in the code, after we call access() to some file, it could be different file with the same name, which we are trying to open.

So /home/flag10/flag10 binary sends arbitrary file with access() permission to some host, port 18211.

We can test it in two screens using:

Our exploit:

entry.title: Exploit-Exercises: Nebula (00-05)
entry.content:
Image: Exploit-Exercises: Nebula (v5)

Because it was not possible to log in via ssh, we generated the host key:

Level00

We found a suspicious file on the first line, after executing, we obtained flag.

Level01

Solution:

Level02

Solution:

Level03

There is a crontab entry that is called every couple of minutes.

Because the /tmp is mounted with nosuid option, we use home directory to store suid binary:

The file invoked by cron is here:

Our code to obtain suid shell:

After a little waiting, the suid binary is created:

Level04

We cannot read the token file, but symlink technique is sufficient:

Level05

In /home/flag05 we can find the backup file with ssh private key.

entry.title: Hackademic: RTB2
entry.content:
Image: Hackademic: RTB2

We gained the IP address 192.168.80.150 for our testing target.

Nmap output:

It seems that the port 666 is filtered by the firewall. After running nmap scan several times, we found the port to be open.

Nikto output for port 80:

The web page suggests to look for SQLi, unfortunately we were not able to find any here.

Trying hydra for bruteforce or joomscan (port 666) reveals us nothing new too.

After a little time, we found SQLi in Joomla and dumped the whole database:

Trying to crack MySQL hashes was without success.

We parse the Joomla usernames and passwords and crack using John:

Because the SQLi statements are executed by database root user, we can read or store arbitrary file to the server.

The target is Ubuntu 10.04, we can predict better the filenames in /etc:

We generate and upload the weevely shell, then upgrade to python shell over netcat:

The following credentials could be used to log in phpMyAdmin using root:

We download the Linux_Exploit_Suggester.pl and use for finding an exploit for privilege escalation:

We root the server using:

We can check the flag here. As we can see from output above, there is port-knocking mechanism using sequences 7000,8000,9000.

Finally we want to see the check.php source:

After decoding the hex characters and converting binary digits in ruby:

So the SQLi test is validated using string compare operator and it’s quite non-realistic (and unfair) to have two statements with the different case, that was the reason why we didn’t found out this firstly.

entry.title: Hackademic: RTB1
entry.content:
Image: Hackademic: RTB1

We gained the IP address 192.168.80.146 for our testing target.

Nmap output:

Nikto output:

There was SQL injection on the web page, vulnerable wordpress instance:

This will take longer and it’s not necessery to dump everything:

Some of the output:

The wordpress could be scanned using wpscan too:

“GeorgeMiller:q1w2e3” has the highest privileges (user_level 10).

We crack the hashes:

We log in using GeorgeMiller’s account and under “Manage -> Files” we upload the generated weevely shell:

We connect using weevely and found out the mysql root password:

Because our web shell doesn’t have assigned tty, we use python to create another reverse shell:

For privilege escalation, we use the following exploit:

entry.title: pWnOS: 2.0
entry.content:
Image: pWnOS: 2.0 (Pre-Release)

Nmap output:

Nikto output:

There is a SQL injection in email, we can see an error message trying to log in (filling an email field with the single quote):

Using Sqlmap we dump the whole databases:

We try to crack hashes but without success in the reasonable time:

With OS Shell functionality of Sqlmap (–os-shell), we was able to obtain shell with the web user privileges:

As we can see, MySQL daemon is running as root (=uid 0), this is also the reason, why we were able to write something with database user to /var/www (owned by www-data), that’s not common.

We can also upload weevely to the remote system and use it as the more sophisticated shell:

We found the database credentials, however they didn’t work:

That was strange, because the web application is connected. After a little more digging, we found this suspicious file:

The blog application uses the text files instead of MySQL. We were only able to locate the password file, without cracking it:

Using root / root@ISIntS we can finally log in via ssh as root:

entry.title: Kioptrix: Level 3
entry.content:
Image: Kioptrix: Level 1.2 (#3)

DHCP client is running on the image and we got assigned this IP address:

We add to ‘/etc/hosts’:

Nmap output:

Nikto output:

After browsing the web page, we can find several vulnerabilities.

SQL injection:

Remote Code execution:

The second one has a Metasploit module that we can use (for LotusCMS):

We invoke a few commands to obtain the shell and upload weevely.

Now we can log to phpmyadmin (found for example by Nikto) with root / fuckeyou credentials:

We found the several interesting things:

In dev_accounts we have:

Using John The Ripper password cracker:

We log as loneferret user and after listing sudo -l we will see that the HT Editor could be invoked.

In editor running with the root privileges we change the /etc/passwd entry according:

We log in as dreg / Mast3r with root privileges and read the congratulation file, there is some information about alternative solutions / exploits:

entry.title: Rattus: Loophole
entry.content:
Image: Rattus: Loophole

Our objective was to find and decrypt the ‘Private.doc.enc’ file. When we boot the image, we can see the network information. With ipcalc we display the possible hosts:

We assign the last IP address from network 10.8.7.0/29:

Nmap output:

Nikto output:

Dirb output:

The most interesting file was http://10.8.7.2/garbage with these hashes:

We were able to crack each one:

Now we can log in as root via ssh, but because this was too easy, we decided to explore samba service too.

The /tmp directory is writable. We can use samba_symlink_traversal exploit in Metasploit:

We suppose we should find ‘garbage’ file this way, but the filename was too predictable for dirb.

We log in as root / albatros and crack the last user (jsummer):

Finally, we find and decrypt the file:

The file that we are looking for has the name ‘csv/Private.doc.enc-aes-256-cbc-decrypted’.

There is even an easier way to decrypt the file, looking to tskier’s home directory:

entry.title: DE-ICE-S1.130
entry.content:
Image: De-ICE: S1.130

Nmap output:

Dirb output:

There is nothing interesting for us except the sysadmin account.

Web page mentions customerserviceadmin@nosecbank.com email address. After a little trying, we found out the user account that exists:

We use hydra to crack user account successfully (ftp was the fastest way):

We log in as csadmin / rocker:

In home directory, there is a clue how to get sdadmin’s password:

Also there is a secord part of some algorithm:

Using this information, we was able to crack the password:

We log in as sdadmin / donovin1998 and repeat the process:

So the dbadmin’s password could be related with the word databaser:

We extract the last part of the email and put everything together:

After fixing minor issues, we compile the code in Java:

We encrypt another usernames to get passwords.

Now we can log as sysadmin. Using sudo:

Because we are in wheel group, we can invoke the command ‘su’ directly to obtain the root access:

From the home directory of sysadmin user, we locate the encrypted file in ftp and use script for decryption, with the password of the root user:

entry.title: DE-ICE-S1.120
entry.content:
Image: De-ICE: S1.120

Nmap output:

Nikto output:

As we can see, Nikto reveals the installation of phpmyadmin and some minor vulnerabilities. There is an information about CVE-2002-0082 too, but we didn’t find any exploit for the issue.

We connect to the web page, add a few products and try sql injection:

We found out that it works so we try sqlmap to dump the whole database content:

This gives us the mysql sha1 hashes. After a small formating, we got:

Trying to login through ssh:

We use one of the accounts to log in and check if there is any user with the higher privileges:

Right, ccoffee is in admin group. For other users it is not allowed to use sudo.

We check his competencies:

There is a script in his home directory that he can execute, unfortunately we cannot read the content. Removing the script and creating a new one with the content ‘sh’ gives root:

We realized that the passwords are different when we reboot the server. Digging deeper, we find more clues:

Finally with this information, we was able to successfully crack the whole /etc/shadow:

There is also a trace that the root user connected via ssh to another server with IP address 192.168.1.20:

entry.title: Kioptrix: Level 2
entry.content:
Image: Kioptrix: Level 1.1 (#2)

Nmap output:

We connect to the web page and log in using username / password (SQLi):

Now we got the access to the “Basic Administrative Web Console”. Trying command injection, we found out that we can inject arbitrary command and execute under web user privileges.

Request / response example:

Web server fingerprints:

We don’t have writable access under DocumentRoot. Looking to different directories, we found the netcat source remains.

So there should be netcat installed, we will need this information later.

We can read index.php for mysql credentials:

The john’s password doesn’t work for ssh, but at least we can extract more from mysql database:

Again, the passwords don’t work for ssh.

We find netcat and use it to bind a shell, then we try to root the box:

Luckily, exploitdb contains local root exploit with exactly this version of kernel:

As our last step, we download and compile this exploit https://www.exploit-db.com/exploits/9542/ .

entry.title: VulnImage: 1
entry.content:
Image: VulnImage: 1

Nmap output:

With dirb we found a few interesting directories (repo, admin, profiles), directory listing is enabled:

Submitting the quote gives an error SQL message:

After a few minutes of playing with requests we realize that we can create files in format ‘username-fname’ and with the content of ‘sig’ parameter.

Now we have a simple PHP shell:

We download the weevely.php from our server and connect:

In the repo directory, we examine the buffd.c. It is a vulnerable daemon, listening on port 7777.

We copy buffd binary from server (/usr/local/sbin/buffd) and using metasploit patterns we calculate the offset for EIP. To make an exploit reliable, we are looking also for some registers, pointing to our pattern in memory.

EIP begins on offset 124 and the register EAX points to the beginning of our buffer, right now filled with pattern. Luckily, we find call eax opcodes in binary too.

The strange thing is that the stack in binary is marked as non-executable, but on this server the exploit works and we don’t get segfault:

Exploit in Ruby:

Exploit runs arbitrary command that we put on vulnerable server to /tmp/commands.

We connect to the host:

To obtain root privileges, we can run ssh server and put to ‘/tmp/commands’ file the instructions to change root password:

Kernel is vulnerable too, using this exploit we can get uid 0 privileges:

In Metasploit is there is another module which we can use to exploit Exim4 (exploit/unix/smtp/exim4_string_format). To make it work correctly, we need to comment the following lines and also change exim to exim4:

entry.title: Holynix: V2
entry.content:
Image: Holynix: v2

We set our network preferences to “Share with my Mac” on both vulnerable server and Kali Linux. Our NIC address will be the following:

Nmap output for 192.168.1.88:

We add to /etc/hosts:

Asking DNS server about the domain reports:

We append these lines to /etc/hosts and try DNS AXFR (zone transfer):

We change our IP address to the IP of the not reachable DNS server and try AXFR again:

Appending the list to /etc/hosts:

Dirb reports the following URLs:

In particular the interesting file was http://www.zincftp.com/setup_guides/todo

Again we set our IP address to match the “trusted.zincftp.com” host, to get access to phpmyadmin:

We found nothing interesting in phpmyadmin, but it’s vulnerable and we can interpret the arbitrary file on web server as PHP script.

We can also try to perform the brute-force attack on ftp users (see /etc/group) and generate the short wordlist with john according username, but without success, ftp connection is limited with the firewall:

After a while we found the hash list for ftp and used the john to crack it:

We uploaded weevely to web directory of tmartin user via ftp:

The kernel was vulnerable (vmsplice, 5092.c) and because weevely shell always logged out root user, we used reverse shell and the writable /dev/shm directory.

On our Kali Linux:

We also found:

If there is not a vulnerable phpmyadmin, we can read the files to table too, according:

1) zincftp_data -> Create new table on database zincftp_data

2) Name = ftp_pass, Number of fields = 1

3) Field = pass, Type = varchar, Length = 100

entry.title: Holynix: V1
entry.content:
Image: Holynix: v1

We set networking in Vmware Fusion as “Share with my Mac” and check the obtained IP address:

Nmap output:

There is a SQL injection in the web login, we submit the following username and password:

Via security (ssp.php) we can disclose arbitrary file (for example /etc/passwd):

With sqlmap we can dump the whole database (%40 means ‘@’ character):

Using sqlmap –passwords parameter we got:

Back to the web page, there is a cookie set as ‘uid=1’. We can try different numbers, because not every user has allowed to upload file, see accounts.csv.

We disclose transfer.php script:

As we can see from the source code, the filename is used in shell command and we can inject malicious input. However the ‘/’ or ‘\’ characters are prohibited, because in $target is stored only the value after (back)slash.

Locator (it never terminates, but confirms our finding):

We can evade the slash restriction encoding the payload as base64 (touch /tmp/owned):

There could be a problem with a bigger input (“filename too long”).

Similarly we upload the following base64 payload redirected to ‘b.php’:

We try our php shell and in the case of success, we upload weevely from our web server:

Note that there exists also a trivial solution, because users can upload php shell to home directory, which can be invoked without any restriction.

If we read the discussion on web server, someone is asking about port knocking. We download the data to our server:

From the vulnerable server, we download and use knockknock too:

We log in as alamo / Ih@cK3dM1cR05oF7.

Because nobody has higher privileges for sudo except www-data, we use the web account to obtain root privileges. One way of doing this is to change using chown /etc/shadow file permission to www-data, move to /tmp and change the root hash to a know one (e.g. alamo’s). Then we move the shadow file back.

In the end we log in as root with Ih@cK3dM1cR05oF7 password:

entry.title: Kioptrix: Level 1
entry.content:
Image: Kioptrix: Level 1 (#1)

Nmap output:

Enumeration of Samba:

The service is running with the root privileges and we can use exploit in Metasploit to obtain root account:

Because Apache is vulnerable, there is another solution. Nikto reports something interesting:

Web server signature:

In exploitdb we find:

Because the exploit is pretty old, we need to update it with these steps:

Finally we run the exploit and cat /etc/shadow with the root privileges.

entry.title: pWnOS: 1.0
entry.content:
Image: pWnOS: 1.0

Nmap output:

After a while of browsing the web page, we found trivial LFI vulnerability:

We can find a lot of information querying the samba service too:

There are a few enumeration modules in metasploit:

The webmin is vulnerable and the exploit in metasploit:

Basically the exploitation could be performed on command line to disclose arbitrary file, for example:

Using john on /etc/shadow, we obtain credentials of user vmware for successful login to the system:

The box could be rooted using standard vmsplice exploit.

However, there is another way to get user account. The script dowkd.pl ensures us that the OpenSSL is vulnerable (CVE-2008-0166).

We download and unpack already generated RSA keys from offensive-security repository:

Because usage of weak private keys could be blacklisted on our server, we use the following instructions to enable them.

Basically adding this directive to our ssh_config file should be sufficient:

In exploitdb, we use python script to try every possible private key:
